>>180308689
>no justifiable reason beyond our own pleasure
That matters quite a lot.

There are other reasons too, for example, maintaining our culture. Food is a large part of all cultures, and eating meat a large part of most of those cuisines. Traditions, celebrations, ceremonies, would drastically change without meat. In many traditional cultures, meat consumption is not every day, it's for celebrations, and the animals are raised openly, in small numbers, with good living conditions. Their suffering is minimal if at all. The question then is not about a practical empathy but about lofty ethics.

Imo the reasonable stance on most ethical/moral issues, is to do better, rather than delusionally think you can be perfect or have no impact. So, free range meat/eggs, only, support political action to tighten regulations for the industry, and eat meat less.
A parallel issue would be, do you never buy or use any products that are produced by workers with poor labour conditions? I doubt it. But you can probably -try- to minimize your consumption and in other ways affect that issue.

>>180311717
this guy is thinking correctly.
It's all fundamentally the same response, and the desire is to not die. Problem is, we can readily observe this tenacity for life in *every single organism*
even some of the not-living things are trying to become alive, it's clearly just a laugh riot up here!
So here again the paradox of life: you want to live, and for you to continue to live, not just one something but many other somethings will have to die. This is a fundamental rule of life, trophic energy levels and all.

this raises a few key issues:
1. there is literally no such thing as ethical consumption. Period. Anything you eat is damned.
2. we ourselves willingly consent to be food to higher level organisms than us by participating in this system. We can see that we are part of a food chain, and assume (correctly, for now we think) that we are the top level of the food chain. What happens when we no longer are? When a bigger fish shows up, can we really decline being casually eaten to extinction as we have done to so many species?
3. Malthusian Trap. It's an inevitable problem in every species that we have observed population booming off of resources, and there is no actual reason to think humans are not just some other animal, and therefore not immune to the laws of nature. Our population is currently booming, eating up resources at an unsustainable rate. Unless we break the system somehow, we are also going to have a massive and violent population collapse after resource depletion. Our only hope really is nuclear fusion, which does kinda break the rules of the game of energy-gathering on earth. Unfortunately, that is heavily reliant on helium, which is rapidly depleting, even for scientific purposes. A lot of very smart people are very quietly panicking about this.

Using the plants growing into the sun as an example,

>The growth of plants toward light is particularly important at the beginning of their lifecycle. Many seeds germinate in the soil and get their nutrition in the dark from their limited reserves of starch and lipids. Reaching for the surface, the seedlings rapidly grow upwards against the gravitational pull, which provides an initial clue for orientation. With the help of highly sensitive light-sensing proteins, they find the shortest route to the sunlight -- and are even able to bend in the direction of the light source.

>"Even mature plants bend toward the strongest light. They do this by elongating the cells of the stem on the side that is farthest from the light. This type of light-oriented growth is called phototropism," explains Prof. Claus Schwechheimer from the Chair of Plant Systems Biology at the Technische Universität München (TUM).

>The substance responsible for cell elongation is auxin. This phytohormone is formed in cells at the tip of the shoot and is then passed from cell to cell. As such, the hormone is shuttled through many cells of the plant before it reaches its final destination. "Export and import proteins push the auxin out of one cell into the intercellular space and then into the next cell and so on until the auxin eventually reaches its target site," outlines Schwechheimer

A chemical reaction, triggered by external stimuli and genetic coding. Plants are complex systems just like us.

>After analyzing the prices of hundreds of commodities, goods, and services spanning two centuries, Marian Tupy and Gale Pooley found that resources became more abundant as the population grew. >>180308689
Cows wouldn't exist anymore without humans. So ask yourself is non existence preferable to existence even if the ultimate purpose of your existence is to be utilized? Cows still roam in pastures, have cow family's and do all the things Cows would do in the wild. But now they are also eaten at the end of their life. Seems like a very good tradeoff.

One must also consider that as soon as a sufficient intelligence emerges on a planet that that foretells the ultimate doom of all other life on that planet. Sooner or later, if humanity is left unabated and progress forever holds to be our ultimate ideal, all other forms of life on said planet will fall into one of a few fates.
1. That life dies.
2. That life's natural habitat is destroyed beyond repair and they must be kept in zoos.
3. That life's natural habitat is preserved solely because we use that life for a purpose.

Cows (and most other forms of food) fall into category 3. They are safeguarded from extinction because of humanities need for them. Most animals fall to the first fate, a "lucky" few (the cute and "majestic" ones) are relegated to life behind bars in zoos and labs.

No. It's not just the cells deteriorating, as your body can replace them. The problem is the telomeres, the ends of the chromosomes. This is why clones don't live very long, they only have the lifespan that the donor had left to live.

I don’t think you know what a non-sequitur is. The whole of season 3 is about juxtaposing the fate of various characters with Tony’s kids, hence Tracee and Meadow, AJ and Jackie. It’s Tony subconsciously wrestling with the fact that that Mafia uses and destroys innocents. In both Tracee and Jackie Jr’s case, both his Mafia code and his own self-centredness cause Tony to fail to protect either of them. The theme of the season is parenting. Tony fails to parent Jackie, just performatively lecturing him, in part because he himself wasn’t parented properly, but also because time and again Tony chooses Mob drama over his family. In addition, Tony fails to respect the vulnerability of Jackie and Tracee in much the same way he despises vulnerability in himself. He expects men to be tough and brutal like himself. I could elaborate further.

You’re fixating on Matt and Sean, who were really there to illustrate the ways the Mafia has evolved, less than anything about Tony’s kids. Matt and Sean expect to be respected and successful simply for their capacity for brute force and violence, but the Mafia has been forced undercover and instead requires cunning and duplicity.

>>180323176
>Yeah, obviously, but tony offered no guidance and no mentorship to cheesefuck either, they weren't fit for the job, and had no one to show them the ropes.
There is no equivalence here. Ironically Matt and Sean even being in this conversation is a non sequitur. Tony had a personal, not professional, obligation to Jackie Jr, which is why there’s a parallel between him and AJ. Tony had no personal or professional obligation to MnS, because there is no such thing as apprenticeships in the Mafia. You get recognition and respect in the Mafia for proving yourself, at which point somebody might take you under their wing, but the point is the Mafia isn’t a trade school. They don’t recruit randoms and mould them, nor do they accept applications. When Matt and Sean signed on with Chris’s crew, it was on them to show that they had the smarts and the guts to get ahead, unfortunately they were both violent morons and so inevitably died.
>they exploit them, and don't help them, all overseen by Tony.
Yes, that’s called being in the Mafia.

>The point you seem to be missing, is that they then repeat the whole same tropes and story arc with jackie
I don’t know if this or your brain on TVTropes but there’s no repetition. The point you can’t seem to grasp is just because there are two instances of stupid young people in the Mob doesn’t mean that’s a repeated “trope”. The characters are radically different and have radically different thematic purposes. MnS demonstrate how far the Mafia have fallen from the glory days, no longer able to flaunt their strength, but forced to engage in surreptitious and underhanded cons. Obviously, they also expose those glory days as simple, stupid brutality, nothing more romantic or glamorous than a rabble of violent, sadistic thugs. Jackie Jr, the son of a boss, demonstrates not how the Mafia professionally culls weak outsiders but how Mafiosi personally doom weak insiders.

posts.com:
Nothing is Lost (You give me Strength), by The Weeknd, appears to have its own stand-alone, official music video now. I like it as a simple companion piece. Not just cuts from the film, but a simple video clip which goes with the singer's usual club-thing and suggests the movie but not in a 1:1 repetition way.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8f3HbKyaEtk

-the figures representing the Na'vi are clearly human actors/dancers representing them, with human build. They are shaded against the action so that we can use our imagination a bit (remembering bits of the movie, or thinking about it slighlty differently).
-there is a figure pretty clearly representing Spider. He jumps off a cliff, as Jake did in the original. As he is also not shown clearly, he blends in with the others.
-Throughout, there is a clear fire-water contrast. This suggests the fires in the film's final act, but it may also suggest the "fire-ash-volcano" people suggested for the third film. Also the hanging Pandora Jelly-things alternate as forest-canopy things and also suggest jellyfish as the camera angle changes, suggesting the story progression.

Really annoyed that a CD copy of the soundtrack isn't available yet, as far as I can tell.

>While in Venice I saw the Anglo-American film "Lolita", a tale about the love between a 40-year-old man and a 12-year-old girl. The film is thoroughly empty and brought me nothing but sadness and disgust as I watched it. The cinema of the future must certainly move away from such hollowness.

>I watched Coppola's "Apocalypse Now". Very weak lead actor and a misguided dramaturgy – cartoonish in execution.

>I attempted to watch "Manhattan". I left in the middle. Monstrous boredom and a totally unglamourous actor [Woody Allen] who tries too hard to be charming.

>The talented French director Jean-Luc Godard, who had previously directed the brilliant "Breathless", showed his new film in Italy – "My Life to Live", a modernistic, pointless exercise. It set outs to tackle a socioeconomic problem (a prostitute's life), but the problem is not only not solved, but not even posed.

>I watched the monstrously disgusting "Possesion", a mix of horror, devilry, violence, noir and everything else. Repulsive. Money, money, money, money... No beauty, no truth, no sincerity, nothing. >>180322582
It's also simply appealing to the audience
Casting older actors to play Lily and James, and even the rest of the adult cast, was obviously a deliberate choice to resonate with the parental and authority-figure expectations of the young children and even adults watching.
The Mirror of Erised scene where Harry finally gets a chance to see his parents would have been far less impactful if they looked like flawless early 20's zoomers, barely different from the seventh years.
Wizards also live longer and seemingly age better than their muggle counterparts, so characters like McGonagall, Molly Weasley, Snape etc. would have probably looked at least somewhat younger than their filmic portrayals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Goblet is the best book, but the second to worst movie, edged out by Deathly Hallows part 2. Yates was just a crap television director, but it's clear why they stuck with him and not the dude that directed Goblet. Goblet is a very long movie, but for some reason it skims over much of the character development in favor of protracted scenes of CGI non-sense. Dragon sequence is overkill. It continued Cuaron's vision of Hogwarts as some kind of cottagecore hipster wonderland, but without any aesthetic filmic style. We have to suffer through Jarvis Cocker playing a prom, and the Patil twins being retconned as Indians, right down to their hideous garb. Worst of all we're introduced to Ralph Fiennes as Voldemort. Highly respected actor, I know, but this guy made for an uninspired interpretation of the villain. He's so generic that he's easily upstaged by Bellatrix in later entries. Obviously the Harry Potter isn't a great movie series, but they really botched what was supposed to be the entry in which the stakes were raised. And the first two movies, as mediocre as they are, are the only films to capture the lived in feeling of the books.

I'll tell you why Prisoner of Azkaban is the best movie and book:
Sirius is a great threat. It's bigger than Dragons, the fuckhuge murder snake, fucking Voldemort.
Partially because of the OP dementors after him (Which seems to have no effect on Sirius) that makes him cooler and more dangerous.
Then there's the buildup:
Sirius is very real and it's after Harry. PERIOD. Not "I trust on Dumbledore's actions" "It's a myth", "I think you are lying" or any handwaving. Sirius is there, and they tell Harry rigth at the start "Harry, Sirius scaped, and it wants to kill you"
Then its first spotted on a town near the school.
Then it's outside the gryffindor common room.
Then is fucking INSIDE THE BEDROOM
Add that to Harry seeing the fucking "omen dog" over and over for added impact.
Also, you have Slytherin shits NOT playing it down
>Haha hope Harry gets killed by the dragon!
>Kwek a giant monster? I hope he kills the mudbloods lol
>We work for the dark lord now ;)
The downplayers were also scared of him.
Add that to the fact that fucking Albus Dumbledore is spotted by Hary saying "Wew Snape, my dude, I have no fucking idea how he got inside my castle!"
Dumbledore, the only man that even Voldemort fears? Well Sirius just stretched his legs on his nose fucking twice.
Overall making Sirius the greatest permanent threat to Harry and a great antagonist, and if it's your first watch, the twist of Sirius being a good guy is a big as fuck payoff.
PoA has the most interesting story, even after substracting the stupid timetravel shenanigans

I re-read them recently as an adult and in general Rowling's pacing is just garbage. Most of the books are 90% dancing around and the plot hardly moving forward until everything plot-wise happens in the last 70-80 pages. The tri-wizard cup being the plot device in the 4th one brings a way better tension>payoff balance because there are constant periods of tension into payoff rather than very slow "where the fuck is this going" into cheap ending. It's also the only one that acknowledges Harry is not special outside his connection to Voldemort, its not afraid to have him be mogged and completely carried by other characters.

As much as people hate to hear it, all three are fantastic contemporary American horror films.
>Get Out: Filters wh*te folk and insults /pol/fags to their face without them realizing it. Exaggeration of the black experience in America framed around a well shot horror film
>Us: Genuinely unnerving at times. Slasher movie based around themes of inequality. Exaggerated as hell, but it's a fucking movie.
>Nope: Commentary on America's obsession with trying to control sentient beings for entertainment and how Hollywood has a direct and negative impact on our lives. Literally chews you up and spits you out.
Just because half of you stomp your feet and cry because he's black doesn't change the fact that he's a pretty good horror director.
That fucking Twilight Zone remake sucked ass. The original existed because they wanted to comment on the American experience and they couldn't do it unless it was framed as a fantasy.
It's not his fault general audience can't understand subtext. They aren't perfect films, but they are well made for what they are.

posts.com:
So I'm sure you've heard the chuds complaining about muh too much diversity, but I for one think that they're not going far enough. The way I see it, film is an art-form like music and.. art. A song can be beautiful, relaxing piano music or even total silence. You want proof? Check out 4'33 by John Cage. Art can be a beautiful landscape painting or a brownish square on a red background to signify inequality. Same with film. Why should anything be a certain way? If you prefer watching war films that's mostly historically accurate, fine. Others might prefer a movie about a dad and his mutant baby. Some might even like both! So why should any character be the same race they are/were irl?

The only thing that bothers me is it's always black, mixed/jews playing characters that were/are white. What's wrong with Asians? Like, why not have Jackie Chan play.. Steve Irwin in a biopic about him? That's just an example, don't do it for real. Jackie Chan is the only living Asian actor I can think of rn. Or how about a film about Abraham Lincoln played by *googles Mexican actors* Michael Pena?

I believe it's even possible to go further than this. Getting Asians and Mexicans is just one more step. We've talked about race, but what about gender if there even is such a thing? How about....*drum rolls* Mr Elliot Page in the role of BISMARK.

The aim of this idea is twofold. More steps on the way to total artistic freedom and maybe freedom in general? If anyone points out what race or gender (if there is such a thing), maybe the film itself will reveal something about anyone who speaks out against it?

Come on Hollywood. Step it up a notch.

On August 5, 1987, while driving a rented BMW 316 on the Tempo Road outside Tempo, Northern Ireland, Broderick crossed into the wrong lane and collided head-on with a Volvo. The driver, Anna Gallagher, 28, and her mother, Margaret Doherty, 63, were both killed instantly.[32][33] He was vacationing with Jennifer Grey, whom he had begun dating in semi-secrecy during the filming of Ferris Bueller's Day Off; the crash publicly revealed their relationship. He suffered a fractured leg and ribs, a concussion, and a collapsed lung. Grey's injuries included severe whiplash, which later required surgery to avoid paralysis.[34] [32] Broderick told police he had no recollection of the crash and did not know why he had been in the wrong lane: "What I first remember is waking up in the hospital, with a very strange feeling going on in my leg." He was charged with causing death by dangerous driving and faced up to five years in prison, but was convicted of the lesser charge of careless driving and fined £100 (US$175).[32][35][36][37][38]

The victims' family called the verdict "a travesty of justice". The victims' brother and son, Martin Doherty, later forgave Broderick amid plans to meet him in 2003.[39] In February 2012, when Broderick was featured in a multi-million-dollar Honda commercial that aired during the Super Bowl, Doherty said the meeting had still not taken place and that Broderick "wasn't the greatest choice of drivers, knowing his past".[40]

posts.com:
So I'm sure you've heard the chuds complaining about muh too much diversity, but I for one think that they're not going far enough. The way I see it, film is an art-form like music and.. art. A song can be beautiful, relaxing piano music or even total silence. You want proof? Check out 4'33 by John Cage. Art can be a beautiful landscape painting or a brownish square on a red background to signify inequality. Same with film. Why should anything be a certain way? If you prefer watching war films that's mostly historically accurate, fine. Others might prefer a movie about a dad and his mutant baby. Some might even like both! So why should any character be the same race they are/were irl?

The only thing that bothers me is it's always black, mixed/jews playing characters that were/are white. What's wrong with Asians? Like, why not have Jackie Chan play.. Steve Irwin in a biopic about him? That's just an example, don't do it for real. Jackie Chan is the only living Asian actor I can think of rn. Or how about a film about Abraham Lincoln played by *googles Mexican actors* Michael Pena?

I believe it's even possible to go further than this. Getting Asians and Mexicans is just one more step. We've talked about race, but what about gender if there even is such a thing? How about....*drum rolls* Mr Elliot Page in the role of BISMARK.

The aim of this idea is twofold. More steps on the way to total artistic freedom and maybe freedom in general? If anyone points out what race or gender (if there is such a thing), maybe the film itself will reveal something about anyone who speaks out against it?

Come on Hollywood. Step it up a notch.
